item.title: With Air Attacks, Sectarian Strife Intensifies in Iraq
item.description: Iraqi soldiers opened fire from helicopters on Sunni gunmen hiding in a village in what seemed to mark a new phase for a conflict that represents a challenge to the Shiite-led government.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: Storied Syrian Mosque’s Minaret Destroyed
item.description: The Umayyad Mosque, a Unesco World Heritage site, has been a battleground for months in the Syrian civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: An image of Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo earlier this month.

item.title: South Korea and U.S. Fail to Reach Nuclear Energy Deal
item.description: South Korea wants to be able to enrich uranium, but the United States worries that this could endanger efforts to curb North Korea’s nuclear ambitions.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: 21 Dead in Clash with ‘Gangsters’ in Western China
item.description: At least 21 people were killed on Tuesday in reported fighting in far western China between security officers and “gangsters,” a regional official said.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: India Ink: How Accurate Is The Prime Minister’s Economic Advisory Council?
item.description: After an optimistic prediction for growth this week, a look back at past council projections.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Different varieties of rice being sold at a shop in New Delhi.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: After Rape of Child, Indian Media and Protestors Make Common Cause
item.description: It was a crime the Delhi police could not have prevented, but the manner in which the police had conducted the investigation gave the protesters the opportunity to cast the capital’s police commissioner as the villain.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: U.N. Expert Says Bahrain Canceled Visit in Torture Inquiry
item.description: The special rapporteur on torture was due to visit Bahrain next month to look into reports that the authorities there had abused and tortured protesters in detention.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Chinese Officials Order Questioning of Chen Guangcheng’s Relatives
item.description: One family member considered the step to be retaliation against stepped-up criticism of the government by the activist, Chen Guangcheng, who is now studying in New York.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Kerry Meets Top Afghan and Pakistani Officials
item.description: The secretary of state met in Belgium with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan and Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, Pakistan’s army chief.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 24
item.description: Fans celebrate cricketer Sachin Tendulkar’s 40th birthday in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Young fans of cricketer Sachin Tendulkar celebrating his 40th birthday in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Could Syria’s Civil War Create Jihadis in Europe and the U.S.?
item.description: European authorities are concerned that hundreds of young Muslims who have gone to fight in Syria will pose a domestic threat when they return home. But there are also concerns that the threat is being overstated, including by Damascus.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Syrian rebel fighters at Aleppo's Umayyad mosque on April 16.

item.title: India Ink: Bollywood Singer Shamshad Begum Dies at 94
item.description: The woman behind the voice that enthralled a generation of Bollywood aficionados died on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: Shamshad Begum, right, being presented with the Padma Bhushan, India's third highest civilian honor, by then president Pratibha Patel in New Delhi on March 31, 2009.

item.title: Fate of Clerics Held in Syria Is Disputed
item.description: Despite reports from a Christian advocacy group and Al Jazeera that two kidnapped Syrian archbishops had been freed, there was no confirmation.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA

item.title: South Korea Offers Aid to Business in Shuttered North Korean Complex
item.description: South Korea had encouraged companies to move operations to North Korea, but then North Korea shut the industrial complex in response to joint American-South Korean military drills.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: WORLD: Same-Sex Marriage and the French Family
item.description: While activists demonstrate over President François Hollande’s politics, French parents debate the legalization of adoption for gay married couples.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Italian President Nominates New Prime Minister
item.description: The nominee, Enrico Letta, deputy head of the Democratic Party, said he would consult with the country’s leaders about its “fragile and unprecedented” political situation.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Enrico Letta, the deputy head of Italy's Democratic Party, was appointed prime minister by President Giorgio Napolitano on Wednesday and tasked with forming a new government.

item.title: Scores Dead in Bangladesh Building Collapse
item.description: An unknown number of people remained trapped after a structure that housed garment factories crashed down near Dhaka.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Letter from India: Indian Government Unable to Deal With Public Rage
item.description: After the rape of a five-year-old girl, the government was unable to produce officials who knew how to employ the language of tactical humility or could at least say the right things in the right manner.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: 21 Dead in Clash with ‘Gangsters’ in Western China
item.description: At least 21 people were killed on Tuesday in reported fighting in far western China between security officers and “gangsters,” a regional official said.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Britain Offers Hand to Smaller Businesses
item.description: A lending program was extended and reworked to free up borrowing to small and medium-size companies, as the nation struggles to avert another recession.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Glimpses From the Life of China’s Jailed Nobel Laureate
item.description: The imprisoned Nobel Peace laureate Liu Xiaobo is reading about Russian intellectuals, Soviet Communism and Christianity, and has put on weight, says a lawyer who’s known his family for years.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo and his wife Liu Xia, left, in an undated photo released by his family in October 2010. Mr. Liu was sentenced to 11 years in jail for subversion in 2009, and awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2010.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Godrej Group Chairman Adi Godrej
item.description: Mr. Godrej offers advice on achieving high economic growth, winning investors’ confidence and more.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:credit: World Economic Forum, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Adi Godrej at the World Economic Forum in New Delhi on Nov. 7, 2012.

item.title: Australia Arrests Self-Proclaimed Head of Hacking Group
item.description: The man, who was not identified, has said he is the leader of a collective known as LulzSec, which asserted it shut down the C.I.A.’s Web site in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 24
item.description: Racing to invest in Indonesia; France approves marriage for same-sex couples; worries about Al Qaeda in Nigeria; worldwide fame for a bakery in Alsace; and bigger prizes at Wimbledon.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: L'Oréal opened its biggest factory in the world in West Java, Indonesia, last November.

item.title: Shakuntala Devi, ‘Human Computer,’ Dies in India at 83
item.description: Ms. Devi’s lightning calculations amazed audiences and supported her family, even when she was a child.
item.dc:creator: By HARESH PANDYA
